Trial_Design.evidence: One hundred patients were randomized to receive cemented THA with either oxidized zirconium or a stainless steel femoral head.

Participants.evidence: One hundred patients were randomized to receive cemented THA with either oxidized zirconium or a stainless steel femoral head.

Intervention.evidence: One hundred patients were randomized to receive cemented THA with either oxidized zirconium or a stainless steel femoral head.

Objective.evidence: We hypothesized that after a minimal 4-year followup (1) use of HXLPE would result in lower radiographic wear than UHMWPE when articulating with a stainless steel head or with an oxidized zirconium head; (2) use of oxidized zirconium would result in lower radiographic wear than stainless steel when articulating with UHMWPE and HXLPE; and (3) there would be no difference in terms of Merle d’Aubigné scores between the bearing couple combinations.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Femoral head penetration was measured using a validated computer-assisted method dedicated to all-polyethylene sockets.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: One hundred patients were randomized to receive cemented THA with either oxidized zirconium or a stainless steel femoral head.

Number_Randomised.evidence: One hundred patients were randomized to receive cemented THA with either oxidized zirconium or a stainless steel femoral head.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Complete followup was available in 86 of these patients.

Result_Outcome.evidence: In the UHMWPE series, the median steady-state penetration rate from 1 year onward was 0.03 mm/year (range, 0.003–0.25 mm/year) in the oxidized zirconium group versus 0.11 mm/year (range, 0.03–0.29 mm/year) in the metal group (difference of medians 0.08, p < 0.001).
